sp.p: Thou shalt be well considered; there is twenty Crowns in earnest.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay Madam, this hand is like a fellow, it takes everything in jest; if you be in earnest, let me feel it here: So Lady, now betwixt earnest and jest, if your Will be ready drawn, before your friend delivered as your deed, and put me in trust to execute it.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Take it, in a word this honest Shepherd, and thy Lords daughter Madam Mopsa, are man and wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Man, an woman perhaps; but not man and wife: for though most women have a will to be Ladies, like my Lords wife; yet every Lady have not wit to be a wife, as my Lords Daughter. But what good can I do in this?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: O very much: for though they be man and wife by oath and protestation, the chiefest ceremony of all; namely Marriage, is yet unperformed, and hearing that you have taken orders.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That I have: I have taken order for the making away of a hundred Maidenheads in my time, and not so few: but I am in in the mind of you now, these two Beagles, Dorus and Mopsa, have run themselves breathless in the chase of love, you would have me couple them up in the leases of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: You are in the right.

sp.speaker: Manass.
sp.p: And you in the wrong, I will keep your jest, but in any case take back again your earnest: I will not purchase my Lords displeasure with your gold.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Thy Lord shall never know it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: O sir! though my M. hath but bad eyes, he hath exceeding long ears: and though a Foreigner may play with a Citizens wooden Dagger, I would not wish any to jest with a Courtiers steeled Sword; it is seldom drawn but it draws blood.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Tush man, be not so timorous, my credit shall countenance thee: be not an Ass, make use of thy time: thy Masters service is no heritage; the world knows he gets under the Duke, thou art a fool, and thou wilt lose under him: there is a hundred Crowns for thee; tush man, thy betters will strain curtsy with allegiance for a bribe.

sp.speaker: Mana.
sp.p: Madam, could you to every one of these Crowns give me a Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I should have more ground than half the Kings in Christendom: here is my hand, I will do it: my M. is my M. and I love him; but my gold is my God, and I honour it: I will do it; the time and place?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Soon in the evening at Adonis Chapel. Art resolute?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: As your Adamant: think you it was fear made me keep out? no it was hope of these flattering sweet lipped drabs. I fear to marry my Ladies daughter? no nor to go to bed with her neither. Why, I have counterfeited his hand and seal. He has been content with me, to come nearer to him, at his entertainment of the last Ambassador, when he was heat with drinking of healths. As I led him to his Chamber, I nimmed his Chain, and drew his Purse, and next morning persuaded him he lost it in the great Chamber at the Revels. He puts me in trust with his whole estate: he buys Manners, I purchase Farms: he builds houses, I pluck down Churches: he gets of the Duke, and I of the Commons: he beggars the Court, and I beggar the whole Country.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: These are notable knavish courses. What breeding hast had?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very good breeding Sir: My great Grandfather was a Rat-catcher, my Grandsire a Hangman, my Father a Promoter, and myself an Informer.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Thou wert a Knave by inheritance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
And by education too: but Bawdy Informations growing stale, I gave up my cloak to a Broker, and crept into credit for a Gown, and of Manasses a penurious Informer, I turned
Copy, and became Manasses, a most precise, and illiterate expositor.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Were you a Reader then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And a Writer too Bully: I set some of my Parishioners Wives such Copies, as their Husbands might cast their caps at it, but could never come near.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: But if you used such a high and elevate style, your auditories low and humble understandings should never crawl over it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Tush I could fashion the body, of my discourse fit to the ear of my auditory: for to cast Eloquence amongst a company of Stinkards, is all one as if a man should scatter Pearl amongst the hoggish animals yclept Swine: no I had paraphrasticall admonitions of all sorts; some against covetous Landlords, and that would I squirt amongst beggarly Tenants: Some against Usurers, and that would I throw in at Prison Grates amongst prodigal Bankrupts: Some against the pride of the Court, and that honeys the ear of the Citizen: Some against the fraud of the City, and that is Cake and Cheese to the Country: Some against Protestants, and that is plumps the lazy Catholic against Papist and Protestant, and that fattens the rank witted Puritan, against Papist, Puritan, and Protestant; and that tickles the ear of the luxurious Atheist.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Why you never light upon any Atheists, do you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: O very many.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: In the Country perhaps, and the outskirts of the city?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: In the very bosom of the City: and by your leave, here and there one in the Court too: But we fixed them all; for indeed we wandering Lights, have (as other tradesmen have) Commodities of all sorts, and prises.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: How do they come by them?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As many do by Offices, steal into them ere the Duke be aware of them.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
Lisa.
sp.p: Methinks Poets of all men, should not edify, they are so envious.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
One to another, to nobody else: a proud Poet is for all the world like a Punk in request, covetous of many Clients, when she hath more than she can handsomely play off: You
shall have some Poet (Apolloes Vicar, especially) write you a comical, Pastoral, Tragical, Musical history in prose, will make the auditors eyes run a water like so many waterspouts: I had one of them myself, if your ears be in case, I will give you a taste on it; his argument was set out of the Poem called, The lost sheep: and thus it is.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Prithee be brief?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay peace, if it were in place where you might wake, the best men in the parish, for commonly they sleep the beginning, because they love not division: but to the lost Sheep. Beloved, you must imagine this Sheep was a Sheep, a lost Sheep; a Sheep out of the way: but my dear flock and loving Sheep, whom like a careful Shepherd, I have gathered together with the whistle or pipe, as it were of mine eloquence, into this fold of peaceful Community; Do not you stray, do not you fly out, do not you wander, do not you lose yourselves; but like kind Sheep, and valiant Rams: I speak to you the better part and head of my flock. As I say, you shall see the valiant Rams turn all their horns together, and oppose themselves against the Wolf, the hungry Wolf, the greedy Wolf, the Lambs-devouring Wolf, the Wolf of all Wolves, to defend their Ewes and young ones. Durst you lay all your heads together, and with the horns of your Manhood defend your families, your own wives, and your neighbours children: Was not this stinging gear?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: A good Sheepish admonition.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The fitter for my Audience: while you live, have a care to fit your Audience.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Thou speakest like a Christian: prithee what Religion art of?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How many soever I make use of, I will answer with Piauano Orllotto the Italian: I profess the Dukes only.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: What is his reason for that?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A very sound reason: for says he, I came Raw into the world, and I would not willingly go roasted out: so close up the stomach of your Discourse with that dry answer, and every man about his business.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You will be mindful of tomorrow night.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: As your Lawyer of the Tearme, or your Landlord of the Quarter day.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why so: the mettle I must forge my plot on, lies a- warming in the furnace of my brain; and I must fashion it Instantly, for fear it burst the heat. Give my conceit way, for here comes one must help to proportion it.

sp.speaker: Damet.
sp.p: How now Demetrius, what wind hath blown up this storm of melancholy, thy countenance was not wont to be thus cloudy? Whence proceeds this sudden alteration?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: From mine own hard fortune my Lord, that my ill-stared nativity should continue thus opposite.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Art crossed in a suit at Court? or what is the matter? speak.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I will acquaint your Honour: I hope no other ear ouer-heares us. Under Dianaes Oak I found an inscription upon a stone, which told me, that wealth Aristomones sometimes brought into Archadea, had there under hid a massie sum of treasure.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Under Dianaes Oak? Dorus shall have my daughter Mopsa; no more words on it, if thou lovest me Dorus: smother thy golden hops a day or two; thou shalt have Mopsa, but I will have all the Gold, then marry my daughter to some great man, though he be poor, it is the fashion: I will be Nobly allied whatever it cost me: shalt be my son-in-law Dorus: have an eye to the Princess, fall close to my daughter Mopsa,
sp.l: Court her and spare not: now begins the sport,
Kiss her, do kiss her; thou shalt pay sweetly for it:
I can gull you, know what fair words can do,
I am an old Knave, and a young Courtier too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: So, so; how violently he devours his bane, and steals himself into the order of Gullery: methinks I see how betwixt hope and fear he sweats in his practise, and like a foolish dreamer, casts how to lay out his wealth before it comes in. So much for him: Now to my Lady Beauty his wife; and as the Devil would have it, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Dorus, how now Dorus? What time of day is it with you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What time of day soever be with me, it is sleeping time with my Lord, I am sure of that.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Sleeping time Dorus, what dost thou mean by that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay nothing: he is troubled with a kind of malady called Insurectio carnis.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: How, a dish of crayfish? nay if that be the worst, good enough: I am glad he falls to Fish, for he was given to Flesh a-late too too bad.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Masse I thought as much, for I saw him go a-angling.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: I hold my Ladyship to some strumpet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Life, a jealousy; I think you are a Witch, it was so indeed.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Nay I thought as much: he was wont to kiss me, and do all kindness a man could do, till he came to the Court; and now he will not lie with me forsooth: and why? it is the Court fashion. He will not love me, and why? it is the Court fashion. I must not come near him at his down lying, nor his uprising, etc. If this be the Court fashion, would I were an honest woman of the Country again, be Courtiers who list. Aye, aye, Dorus, I tell thee in tears, he hath not done by me, as a Husband should do.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: It is nothing to me, I cannot do withal Madam, would I could.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Yes marry mayst thou Dorus; thou mayst, and shalt do withal too and thou wilt: but as thou lookest to enjoy my daughter Mopsa, acquaint me with the old Foxes starting hole.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That is past my cunning: the old Fox has more holes than one, to hide his head in: But not to go long about the bush with you.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: No good Dorus, I do not love a man should go long about my bush: What is she for a woman?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I know not what she is for a woman; marry I fear she is little better than a Whore for your Husband: hark in your ear; she is Manasses wife.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Manasses wife? marry fire Master gunner; a Puritan turned Punk: Gods my precious. I will slit her nose, as I am a Lady will I: is she the party you wot on?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes faith Madam, she is the Mare the man rid on.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: I will spoil their sport, saddle my Mule there, have an eye to the princess: shalt have my daughter if be but to spite him withal, faith Fox I will have you out of your hole, or I will fire you out.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay that will do no good, but for your own good Madam, take heed you do not scold.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Why may not a Lady scold Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Scold, O in no case, it will mar a Ladies beauty clean, and make her look as hard favoured as any ordinary woman.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: God-a-mercy for that Dorus, I will not lose my beauty for twenty on them: saddle my Mule, bring me my chopping knife, I will geld the lecherous Goat, and mince his Trull, as small as herbs to the pot. This is not scolding Dorus, is it?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No this is tolerable.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Nay then I care not, saddle my Mule I say, let her pray God her feeling be good, for as I am a Lady, I will not leave her an eye to see withal, and yet I will not scold neither.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O take heed of that at any hand, So, so, so: now it begins to quicken methinks, I see already how she runs a tilt at the Wenches eyes: calls the maid Bawd, the woman Whore, and her husband Lecher: and when all comes to all, like an Irish Wolf, she barks at her own shadow; but committing her and her Ass to their wildgoose chase: now to my sweetheart Mopsa, for she is all the blocks last in my eye to stumble on: and God bless my wits, for the fool haunts me.

sp.speaker: Mops.
sp.p: Dorus, where is my Father Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your Father, O my dear Mopsa?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay now you flout me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Flout you? o the fair heavens, but this it is for a man to cast away himself in violence of passion and extremity of sighs on a piece of beauty, that cares not for him, but it is the trick on you all.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Tricks, no as god mend me, and I should not have a husband till I got him with tricks, I should lead apes in hell: but faith tell me, dost thou love me Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Do I love you quoth ye, It cuts my very heart strings, do I love you? why it is the only mark my Endeavours shoot at.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: If thou dost not hit the mark, then thou art a very bungler: but where is my Father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why I have sent him and your mother out of the way of purpose, and appointed Manasses to meet us this evening at Adonis Chapel in the Amasons apparel, to marry us: I think this are signs I love you.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Aye but you jest, I doubt you will not marry me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Will you meet me there?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I am a Virgin I will.

sp.speaker: Dor,
sp.p: And come with an intent to marry me?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I hope to be a wife I will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You must take heed you keep our purpose close,

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I did the loss of my Maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why have you lost it then?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Many a dear day ago, yet I told Nobody of it but my Mother and our Horsekeeper, and they say I am never the worse maid for that, if I can keep my own counsel, as I hope I shall; but will you meet me soon?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Just in the mid-way, as Tilters do.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I will go afore and stay, but do not deceive me, if you do, I will show my Fathers Horsekeeper all as God mend me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: So tria sequntur tria, now am I rid of a triumvirate of fools, and by their absence have won a free access to an escape.
sp.l: If my Lisanders hope prove like to this,
This night shall Crown us Monarchers of our bliss.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No more of these delays sweet Madam, your love hath broken day oft with my expectance, I dare give it trust no longer.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I confess it my Liege, and like a spent Dear, not able to maintain longer flight, I cast my self down breathless at your loves mercy: yet I beseech your Majesty, let not your eager desires, practise any present violence upon my yielding chastity: it was only possession of my love you had in chase, which with convenient time and place purchased, I put your grace in full possession of.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
Although thy Breath be never but Musical, yet it never taught the string of true happiness till now: and to approve thy
heart sets hand to thy word, appoint the time.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Then this present evening (and yet my Virgin blood, and ashamed to consent to the betraying of my modesty) meet me at Adonis bower, where I will make tender of subdued chastity to your high Majesty, as my first and most victorious conqueror.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: By my Imperial Globe, and hope of those Joys, thy presence shall bring to enrich me with, I will meet thee, and make thee Queen over the most submiss Captive that ever love took prisoner.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: If you deceive me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not except warm life,
Deceive my voice of their innative heat.
Then hast slow time, exchange thy leaden fleet,
For Hermes wings till I my fair hopes meet.
But locked once in the arms of my delight,
Cloth all the world in an eternal night.
And steed of morning when the Sun should rise,
They shall see two in my Zelmanes eyes.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: So farewell thought I, I have prepared you a Zelmanes answerable to your expectation.
Then triumph in thy will, and let thy thoughts
Proclaim a Jubilee: my teeming hopes
Are now delivered of a gracious birth,
Which I have Christened, opportunity.
Unto whose shrine in honour of this day,
My thoughts shall hold a monthly sacrifice.
Love grant Demetrius, meet the like success,
Our pains are crowned with double happiness.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Only our disguises hold firm, but all other attempts meet untimely deaths, even in their cradles.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: What if we should acquaint the Ladies with our intents.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p:
It would argue a kind of cowardice in our wits, that have such suspectless admittance to their presence, as this disguise hath purchased us, we should not have that ability of inventure to entangle them
in their own security.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Well howsoever, we must not dwell long determining for the liberty of stay with Dametas, who out of his covetous disposition in detaining our reward, allowed us the eldest day of our licent abode at Court, is run out.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: It is very true, and for my part, I will rather go home with a private repulse, than managing any unlikely attempt, become sufferer under a public disgrace.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: That is my very thought, yet that our second arrival be not altogether empty of employment, let us practise something upon Dametas, and acquaint the world with his coward baseness; in which, he not only detracts from his masters bounty, but look how as Conduit head or master-spring that is poisoned, doth his best, to infect the whole body of the court, with the leprosy of his covetousness.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: There is no action of his begetting can be said to be truly honourable.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: How can they when their Father is a mongrel, the Duke out of his honourable bounty commanded him to reward our travails with two hundred Crowns: and now after two months attendance and enforced delays: In which time an ordinary petitioner might have spent the value of the reward, he packs us off with fifty Crowns, his excuse being that his master hath forgot us, and what he doth, is of his own bounty, as if the Moon should brag she gave the world light, when all the luster she hath, comes from the heat of the Sun.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: Should his villainies be suffered to prosper, they would grow to such height, as the Dukes authority should have much trouble to prune them.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: To prevent which, his majesty shall have private note of it, knew we in whose trust to conduct it.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.p: It is an Office very few dare undertake, he is so riveted to the Dukes good opinion.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Lies there no jar twixt none of the Nobility and him, what say you Zelmanes?

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: The gallant Amason: you could not have cast your choice fitter, for her honourable mind maintains deadly feud against his base proceedings: and here she comes, attended by Dametas servant, let us wait on opportunity.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Lisander.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Iulo.
sp.p: Lisander and Demetrius, stand close, of my life we are come to the birth of some notable knavery.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: How blows the winds of our hopes?

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.p: Fair to the point of our expectation, I have made away the Duke and the Dutch.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How made away them? poisoned them.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: with a confection of love, which I have so tempered with fair promises, as their minds are in loves heaven already: Uidelicet in Adonis bower, where this evening I have given them my word to meet them; but I have so cast it, that Manasses shall meet them in my steed.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: It will be a rare scene of mirth, to hear what costly discourse they will bestow upon the fool in thy outside.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Do you hear that.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.p: yes, thank love and my ears, but list the conclusion.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I have cleared the way to Violetta, but what order hast thou taken, with thy burbolts: Dameta, Myso, and amorous Mopso.

sp.speaker: Damet.
sp.p: shot them away, at three several marks, yet so conveyed it that in the end they shall all meet at Adonis chapel.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: This project cannot but bring forth some notable deceit.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: My hopes should want of their will, if it do not.

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.p: Now we have made a smooth passage to our escape, how shall convey our lover out of the Island.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I have determined of that sir, and better to effect, my boy this time hast cast such a bait of knavery to the two Captains, Kalader and Philinax, as we may pass without suspicion.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: But how for transportation.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: I am furnished of that too, you remember the two Lacedemon intelligencers

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Now what of us.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Hold my life, we shall be put in this scene of gullery.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: O in any case.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: For the love of Cupid do, inquiry is past, let us take our entrance, and pass over the stage like mutes, to furnish out a show.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p:
And see occasion like a kind wench presents them in the very instant my honest friend welcome, have you not your dispatch
with a letter to Lacedemon.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: Madam we have, and stay only to take our leaves of your Ladyship, and know what service your honour will command.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: you have my thanks, for the truth is, I must commit business of much import unto your trust, and to prevent much circumstances take my word, you are not ignorant of the kings general challenge.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: About his daughters.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: you understand me, with these few crowns receive my mind which is to convey the two ladies whom we in these disguises have worn to Lacedemon,

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: were we but confirmed of your of estates.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: we will give your sufficient assurance of that and the princesses themselves shall confirm it.

sp.speaker: Iulo,
sp.p: we crave no better madam, but shall we not have yours honours company.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: No: having brought them aboard, we will make return to the Duke, to let him understand we stole not our prizes but worn them manfully at the point of wit.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: A noble resolution.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: His foil will appear the more palpable, and your conquest the more applausable, where shall we receive the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Be that our care, but on your lives be heedful of your safeties.

sp.speaker: Amt,
sp.p: More than of our own my lord,

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Enough whilst you attend we will to the Duke, and play all gulls or none.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: All Gulls indeed since you had follies whip,
No gulls, to all gulls, fools love fellowship.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Look well to mine Ass there, lord how I sweat with anger; this same is the house sure, and now like a wise Lady let me count my hurts, and see how I shall be revenged: it shall be so, I will have them both carted, and manasses shall go afore like a whisler and make way with his horns, where be these whores: open the door, where be these panders: O that I were not a lady: I could scold like a butter-whore,
who is there a-gods- name, lord for his mercy is the woman mad.

sp.speaker: miso:
sp.p: yes I thank ye for it: horn mad, where is your companion where is the old lecherous goat my husband, open the door I say.

sp.speaker: wife.
sp.p: Jesus for thy mercy sake madam, what do I want.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: what do I want, the chief implement a woman should have I want that as a woman cannot be without, I mean my husband, I want.

sp.speaker: wife
sp.p: your husband, I saw him not as I am an honest woman.

sp.speaker: mi.
sp.p: not as you are an honest, so I think, but as you are an arrant whore you did, you must have your Crayfish with a pox cannot City Maunchet and fresh cod serve your turn, but you must have Court cake-bread and Crayfish with a vengeance, but come give me my husband, or I will have him out of the flesh on thee, and yet I will not scold neither.

sp.speaker: wife
sp.p: Pray Madam have patience: what should your husband do here

sp.speaker: mis.
sp.p: That which he should do at home with his wife, if he were worth his ears. wife,
Lady I protest I do not know him,

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Not know him, thou liest in every vain in the heart thou liest, thou knowest him, and as Adam knew Eve thou knowest him, he hath been as inward with thee, as ever he was with me, he hath by his own confession he hath, if thou deniest it, thou liest in thy throat like a Puritanical whore as thou art, O that I were a butter-whore for an hour I might scold a little.

sp.speaker: wife
sp.p: Madam they are no honest men that bring these tales to you

sp.speaker: mis.
sp.p: Men bring tales to me, I defy thee in thy guts, I defy thee, men bring tales to me, thou takest me to be one of thine own church dost: they are no honest men that bring tales to thee and have wives of their own, and my husband is one of them, go thy ways now.

sp.speaker: wife.
sp.p: I beseech you madam do but hear me.

sp.speaker: mis,
sp.p: Hear thee, I have heard too much of thee, too too much too much, where is my husband, bring forth my husband, I will teach him to put a difference betwixt Ioan and my lady I hold him ten pound on it, and yet I will not scold neither, if I had been an old hag past teaming as his whore is a puritan, it had bid somewhat, but being a woman of Gods making, and a lady of his own, and wearing mine own hair which is much in a lady of my standing I can tell you, to use me thus, flesh and blood cannot endure, let me come in, open the door let me come in, O that I were any vile thing in the world but a lady that I might scold a little.

div1.stage: Enter Kalander and philanax Demet, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
So, so, so, take your places, for the same bald pated oak is the stage, where ye shall see the part of a doting fool performed by an old man and a young wench,
Do worshipful Dametas,
The same man,
Hath he no fellow actors in his most lamentable, comical, historical, tragical, musical, pastoral.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: None that require any mouthing but his Ass and himself, marry then he has Signer Mattock, a very sharpe satiricall humorist, and Mounser le spade, but he goes somewhat more bluntly to his business, yet he will serve for mutes, and as good as the best to furnish out the stage.

sp.speaker: Kal,
sp.p: But dares Dorus being but Dametus servant so abuse his mad master thus grossly.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: O Lord Sir, there have been serving men have done their Masters far greater abuse, yet had their wives concealed it, their ears should never have been acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is that a fashion in request.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Altogether I will assure you, but obedience Gentleman the sean begins.

div1.stage: Enter Dametas with mattocke and spade

sp.speaker: kal.
sp.l: Pray God it be good he stays so long,
Ridiculous enough, and good enough.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: So, stand Ass, stand gentle Ass.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: What countrymen is his Ass he speaks so familiarly to him.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: of the City breed, marry he picks up his living of the burs and nettles that grow about the Court gate.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: be in readiness good mattock, play thy part sweet spade, let me see Dianaes oak? I held Dianaes oak divine, true pure gold honest, Dorus, fortunate Dametas.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: An excellent comedian, what life he puts into his part.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: So, by thy leave stone, by thy patience honest stone, the very gravel savours of treasure, this same is the bed chamber of my Lady Pecunia, and see, see some of her golden hairs, more, more, more yet divine tree, pure gold, honest Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, softly, softly, not too fast, let me not devour my content too greedily lest like a cormorant I take a surfeit of it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O take heed of that master in any case.

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p:
Pure mettle, excellent gold: but let me see now, I shall by computation have some three millions of them, aye some three or four millions, how shall I employ them to make the most profit of
them.

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p: That would be known indeed.

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p: I will put out one million to use, after the rate as seven score to the hundredth: and yet I will not, no fie, for then you will have my humour brought on the stage for a usurer; to prevent with scandalous report, I will put it into my Scribe-maiors hand, and he shall deal for me.

sp.speaker: Kal:
sp.p: There is a simple cloak to cover his villainy.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: It is a very short one,: and passing slight to hide his knavery.

sp.speaker: boy.
sp.p: it cannot chose but be seen through.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Another Million I will lay to bestow in Offices. I will have wealth or I will rake it out of the kennels else, chimneys have smoked for already, and now I will deal upon sea-cole and salt, now, now, now, it comes, sweet gold, honest Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, divine gold, how, how, shall I adore thee, O let me do the homage of my knees: now now, for the tongue of a Poet, though I hate poetry worse than any of the seven deadly sins, I could wish myself a Poet for some hour, to write a Poem in the praise of my divine mistress; and see the very bed wherein her divinity is lodged: happy, happy, thrice happy Dametas, now like an oreioid lover, let me open the sheets of my heavenly mistress, with reverence, so with humble reverence, and like a blushing lover that puts out the light ere he presumes to touch the bed of his love so let me darken the candles of my body, mine eyes, and first bless my hands with touching, next enrich mine ears with hearing, and lastly make happy my eyes with seeing, and let them convey the joy down into the bosom of my thoughts, by degrees, softly by degrees.

sp.speaker: Phi:
sp.p: Did you ever see Ass make such a ceremonious preparation

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: be not offended sweet mistress that I presume to touch,

sp.speaker: phil:
sp.p: a fools head of your own,

sp.speaker: Kal:
sp.p: Has he been at any cost of all this invocate for a coxcomb and a bell.

sp.speaker: phil:
sp.p: beshrew my judgment but he deserves it,

sp.speaker: boy:
sp.p: If his desert were never so much, he could but bear away the bell, and so you say he doth:

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: A coxcomb and a bell, o indignity: damnable oak, vile and evil accursed Dorus, unfortunate Dametas, Diana I tell thee thou art no honest goddess to use a Gentleman thus. What is here a writing, your help good spectacles, lend me your help good spectacles, some comfortable news good spectacles:
sp.l: Who hath his hire hath well his labours placed,
Earth thou didst seek, and store of earth thou hast.
He that vain hopes pursues for love of pelf,
Shall lose his wits and likely find himself,
Then think thy pains rewarded well,
Thou brought the fool, bear back the bell:
Of other matters what ensues
Adonis bower shall tell the news,
sp.p: Villainous poetry, I am made a flat fool by poetry, But though I can do them no further disgrace, my fatal curse, a Wronged gentleman's fatal curse dwell ever upon them, Diana Hear me, and let my words find gracious acceptance.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: Hide your heads, the terrible curse comes like a stone upon you

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Rancour, spite, malice, hate, and all disasters,
Strengthen my faith against all protestors.
May their intents though pure as crystal glasses,
Be counted faults and capital trespasses,
O may their lives and laboured industry,
Though worthy of Apolloes plaudit be
The clearest thought in loyalty excelling
Be by some Door presented for libelling,
when they have writ a scene in which their brains,
Have dropped their dearest sweets, and their swollen veins,
Emptied their Conduits of their purest spirit,
As they stand gaping to receive their mertit,
Instead of plaudits their chiefest blisses
Let their deserts be crowned with mews and hisses:
Behind each post and at the gallery corners,
Sit empty gulls, 'slight fools and false informers,
Let some sly Fox out of discretions embers,
Term them the lands unnecessary members,
And like the dear when they have spent their breath,
to make kings sport let them be torn to death,
Even by their friends, it would set my thoughts a-twanging
Might I but see one of them go to hanging.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: A passing strange curse and no question he has travelled far for some of the rimes,

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: He must travel further that finds any reason in it,

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: No matter for reason there is rime enough if that be good.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: Some of it is no better than it should be, or my judgment deceives me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p:
Sure he had some reason to make this rime,
and a man could pick it out,

sp.speaker: 2 cap,
sp.p: rather than I will be counted inquisitive, mine ears shall content themselves with the rimes only, and leave the reason to the scanning of poets whom it more nearly concerns.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap,
sp.p: But where is the wag that invited us to this banquet of mirth shrunk in the wetting?

sp.speaker: 2 cap:
sp.p: it were a rare jest now if whilst the boy kept us here in expectation of Dametas gullery his M: had made an escape with the duke's daughters,

sp.speaker: 1 cap:
sp.p: that or some knavery else upon my life, I had the boy in shrewd suspicion at the first.

sp.speaker: 2 cap.
sp.p: And this his sudden and stolen departure, confirms it currant

sp.speaker: 2 cap:
sp.p: then we are sped, for in suspicions face, I see some subtle stratagem in chase.

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: Will your lordship believe me now: nay if I say it your worship may swear it, though I have but a (poor as to say) hole of mine own I hope the spirits have more denomination over me, than to make it a common slaughter house of carnality where every iacke may command flesh for his money,

sp.speaker: miso:
sp.p: No more words sweet woman I confess I was in the wrong, there is not the hole the Fox hides his head in: and therefore for the love of womanhood conceal mine errors, for howsoever I complained it is thy forehead aches, thy temples have the terrible blow as they say, thy husband is a bad man.

sp.speaker: Wife,
sp.p: my husband:

sp.speaker: miso:
sp.p: Aye, aye, good woman thy husband: he is as I say a fleshly member and I fear he hath overcome the foolish thing my daughter.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: your daughter I will slit her nose by this light if she were ten ladies, it was not for nothing my husband said he should meet her this evening at Adonis chapel, but if I come to the god speed of it, I will tell them of it soundly?

sp.speaker: miso:
sp.p: Aye do good woman tell them of it, and spare not but in any case do not scold.

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: Why may not a gentlewoman scold in a good case:

sp.speaker: miso:
sp.p: I know not what a gentlewoman do in a good case, but a lady must not in any case:

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: though I may not scold I may tell them roundly of it I hope,

sp.speaker: miso:
sp.p: that may you do law,

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: and I will not be mealy mouthed I warrant them, will you bear me company to the chapel madam?

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: with all my heart mistress, what Dorus hath given me, I will give my friend, no fool to company.

div2.head: scena prima.
div2.stage: Enter the duke at adonis bower

sp.l: Farewell bright sun thou lightener of all eyes
thou fallest to give a brighter beam to rise.
Each tree and shrub were trammels of thy hair,
But these are wires for none but kings to wear,
And my rude tongue striving to blaze her forth,
Like a bad artisan doth disgrace her worth,
but here is the place, upon this crystal stream:
Where Citherea did unyoke her team
Of silver doves, to interchange a kiss
With young Adonis shall I meet my bliss:
The gentle minutes crowned with crystal flowers,
Loosing their youths, are grown up perfect hours,
To hasten my delight, the bashful moon
that since her dalliance with Endimion,
Durst never walk by day is under sail,
Instead of sheets has spread her silver vail,
Each gliding brooke and every bushy tree
Being tipped with silver were her livery,
And the dim night to grace our amorous wars,
Hath stuck nine spheres full of immortal stars,
Instead of pearls the way on which she treads
Is strewed with Crystal dew and silver beads.
She comes, her feet makes music with the ground,
And the chaste air is ravished with the sound,
My soul flies forth to meet her: hell my wife,
Her presence like a murtherer drives the life
Out of my pleasures breast, her jealous eye
Envies the heaven of my felicity.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Zelmane, or my husband life or hate.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What makes old Autumn out of bed so late,
that snow should go a-wooing to the sun
When one warm kiss works her confusion.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I have the jest, suspicion that keeps
Court in my husbands thoughts, seeing my love,
Elect this walk, hath brought him after him.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: She dogs her sure, and she to shake her off
Hath taken some other walk I will place mine ear
in distance of her will.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Could I but hear the innocent delivery of his breath, it would be a second jubilee of mirth.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Here comes my love.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: your love? Alas poor Duke,
sp.l: Your forward hopes will meet a barren spring,
My sun appears.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Fie your love speaks too loved,
Your sun is eclipsed, your date upon a cloud.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: See how his arms like precious phoenix wings,
Spread to embrace me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Now the Cuckoo sings,
Those amorous arms do make a golden space
To hug a Duke.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: But I will fill up the place.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Those fingers tipped with curious porphyry,
Staining Pigmalions matchless imagery,
Like amorous twins all of one mother nursed,
Contend in courtesy who should touch me first.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: should touch me first: their strife is undertook,
To twine a young bay not a far-stooping oak.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Young bay, stale jest, that a dry sapless rind
should hold young thoughts, and a licentious mind,
Were he but gone now.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.l: Were the Duke away,
My hopes had got the better of the day.

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: This is Adonis chapel, I wonder they come not, though I bear a little learning about me, and a few good clothes, I would not wish them to make Balams ass of me: for though many fools take no felicity but in wearing good clothes (though they be none of their own) I have a further reach in me.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: I could ban my stars.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.p: I curse my fate.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: That cross me thus.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.p: Make me unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: Alas good lady, how her pretty feet labour to find me.

sp.speaker: dut:
sp.p: that my hopes should meet such black events.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: O would the friendly night darken herself.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Would the Moon lose her light,
That in the bosom of some foggy cloud
I might embrace my love.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: But night is purblind
To make a Duke a slave.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: To make a Duchess
wrestle with amorous passions.

sp.speaker: Duk,
sp.l: life a spleen
Could my rough breath like a tempestuous wind,
Blow out heavens candles, leave the world stark blind,
That it might either have no eyes to see:
Or use those eyes it hath to pleasure me.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Or use those eyes it hath to pleasure me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Who would have thought the cold had been so good a musician: how it plays upon my chaps, and maketh my teeth skip up and down my mouth like a company of virginal Iackes, but I find small music in it, and Mopsa should come now I could do her little good, yet if she were here, she and I would have about at cob-nut or at cherry-pit or somewhat to keep ourselves from idleness, though she be but a fool, the babble is good enough to make sport withal in the dark and that very word hath started her.

sp.speaker: Mop,
sp.p: who is there Manasses.

sp.speaker: man,
sp.p: yes Mopsa.

sp.speaker: mop.
sp.p: plain Mop. I might be madam Mopsa in your mouth, goodman etc. where is Dorus.

sp.speaker: man,
sp.p: why because he will not be said to make too much hast to a bad bargain, he is not come yet,

sp.speaker: mop,
sp.p: not come, a peascod on him, but all is one I thought at first he would make but a fool on me.

sp.speaker: man,
sp.p: would you have him mend Gods workmanship?

sp.speaker: mop,
sp.p: But chose him, since he hath buld me with an urchin, I will go fetch Raph our horsekeeper, let him that got the calf keep the cow in a knaves name if he will, have you your book here.

sp.speaker: man,
sp.p: no matter wench, I can dote well enough without book,

sp.speaker: mop.
sp.p: Nay if ye can dote well enough yourself, I care for neither of them both, but indeed I love to have a thing well done, for says my mother, a thing once well done, is twice done, and I am in her mind for that up and down,

sp.speaker: Dut,
sp.l: Who is with my Lord the Duke, it cannot be,
Mine eye would not conceal such treachery.

sp.speaker: Dut,
sp.l: It is not the Duchess sure, no it is amorous Ioue,
that seeing Zelmane passionate for love,
Descends to comfort her, Ioue if there be
A powerful Phebus God of poetry,
In dear remembrance of fair Daphnes rape,
to win my love, lend me some stranger shape,
Such as yourselves have worn, that when your fame
is sung by poets, they may cote my name,

sp.speaker: Dut,
sp.p: Sure it is my daughter,

sp.speaker: Duk,
sp.l: Daughter: how her eye
Cuts out new forms, new shapes of jealousy:

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: As sure as death it is she, for see they stand
like amorous twins, entwisted hand in hand,
Breast against breast, and that no joy be missing,
To hear discourse, their lips keep time with kissing,
I will not endure it impatience grow strong,
And though a prince, tell him he doth thee wrong.

sp.speaker: duk
sp.l: Do prithee do, this sweetens all the rest,
But here would be the elixir of the jest,
if whilst we kept each other at a bay,
A third should come, and bear the hare away.

sp.speaker: dam.
sp.p: villainous poetry, unchristian poetry, I am cozened of my gold by poetry, robbed of my charge by poetry, made an apparent fool by poetry, villainous Oak, accursed Dorus, unfortunate Dametas: who is there my daughter and with Zelmane? a well-willer to Dorus, a favourite to poetry, and therefore enemy to Dametas, come hither mopso, on thy fathers blessing come not near her: what Mopsa.

sp.speaker: mop.
sp.p: yes, who is there? Dorus.

sp.speaker: dam.
sp.p: Confusion of Dorus, I am thy miserable father, didst not see Hippolita,

sp.speaker: mop.
sp.p: no by my troth not I? Did ye not see Dorus.

sp.speaker: dam.
sp.p: Pox of dorus I am undone madam if thou tellest me not of Hipolita,

sp.speaker: mo,
sp.p: Pox of Hippolita, I am a dumb woman and you can tell me news of Dorus

sp.speaker: da,
sp.p: I had rather see ten doruses hanged than lose Hippolita,

sp.speaker: mo,
sp.p: I had rather see ten fathers damned than lose my sweet dorus,

sp.speaker: da,
sp.p: I shall run mad if I find not Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Mop:
sp.p: I shall run frantic if I find not Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.p: What is here, I shall run mad for Hipolita.

sp.speaker: duke:
sp.p: And I shall run frantic if I find not Dorus, I hold my life we have some comedy in hand, we shall have a full scene, for here comes more actors.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: As sure as I am a sinner to God madam, that same is he.

sp.speaker: muso
sp.p: What with a brace of wenches, I'faith old brocke, have I taken you in the manner, is this the fruits of your lying alone? is this your court custom with a wanton, lend me thy knife, though I had neither house, nor land to give them, I will bestow a whores mark betwixt you, and yet I will not scold neither.

sp.speaker: mep:
sp.p: What a gudyere ail you mother, are you frampold, know you not your own daughter.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Mopsa, O insufferable wrong, make thine own natural child thy bawd,

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: Here is an excellent pattern for wives to learn to scold by

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: What mistress Amason, have you such a cocking spirit, honest Women cannot keep their husbands at home for you: it is not for nothing now I see, that the Duchess looks yellow on you, but I will tear that painted whores face of yours (by this light) and yet I will not scold neither.

sp.speaker: man
sp.p: Madam,

sp.speaker: miso:
sp.p: I will mad you with a vengeance.

div2.stage: The duke and dutches step both forth and restraine her.

sp.speaker: dut,
sp.p: Touch not the prince.

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: On your allegiance forbear, what means this outrage, cannot our private walks be privileged from your wild contentions.

sp.speaker: dut:
sp.p: how fares the prince.

sp.speaker: duk:
sp.p: How cheers my good Zelmane?

sp.speaker: man:
sp.p: Zelmane, no Gods my judge my liege, I am Manasses, miserable Manasses, your husbands scribe-maior madam.

sp.speaker: dut:
sp.p: Manasses.

sp.speaker: duk:
sp.p: A fool.

sp.speaker: mis.
sp.p: My man.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: And my dear head, alas sweet love, what makest thou here.

sp.speaker: m,
sp.p: Marry work for the hangman, if the Duke be not the more merciful.

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: There is some deceit in this, Dametas, where is Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Aye, aye, there is some knavery in this: Mopso where is Hippolita?

sp.speaker: mis:
sp.p: doubtless there is some villainy in this, Mepso where is Hipolita?

sp.speaker: mep:
sp.p: There is no plain dealing in this, Manasses where is Dorus?

sp.speaker: Gry:
sp.p: Answer directly, where is Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Alas madam I know not, whilst I almost melted myself with digging of gold in Dianaes oak, I left her in my wives charge

sp.speaker: wife
sp.p: And whilst I ran to Manasses, thinking to take my husband and his wife in the manner, I left Hipolita in my daughters chamber

sp.speaker: man:
sp.p: and whilst I came to Adonis chapel to be tossed in my marriage blankets with Dorus, I left my little dog pearl plucking daisies:

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: Who sent you to Dianaes oak to dig gold?

sp.speaker: Gry:
sp.p: who sent you to take your husband in Manasses house?

sp.speaker: wife:
sp.p: dorus.

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: who sent you to Adonis chapel.

sp.speaker: mep:
sp.p: dorus:

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: And who turned you into this shape:

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: They that I fear have made gulls of us all, Zelmane, and dorus:

sp.speaker: duke:
sp.p: we are all simply gulled, and see where the Sun scarce half ready, skips from his Eastern bed, smiling at our gullery:

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Come where is this lusty wit-maister.

sp.speaker: Lisa:
sp.p: the keeper of this love-lottery,

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: This gallant Iuventus of fourscore, that like my Lady of the Lake, displays against all comers.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: May a couple of plain witted princes have a sight of your prizes:

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Where be these Ladies ha? have your wits had such a skirmishing that the two maids have lost their heads in the conflict.

sp.speaker: dut;
sp.p: Heads, aye and bodies too my Lord, and all at one shot, and which is worse our wits are so scattered with the terrible blow that to be plain we are scarce our own men again.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: then you have had some knocking,

sp.speaker: mun:
sp.p: so it appears by the story my Lord:

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: How say you my lady, what Owl sings out of that Ivy bush

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: was your wit knighted in this last action:

sp.speaker: man:
sp.p: I am not such a fool, I love my lord, I am no knight, I am Manasses, they made a plain fool.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: the only were, for the guarded fool is out of request: but faith my liege how did your opposites behave themselves, did they win the Wenches fair at the point?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: At the very push of invention, and went off clear untouched,

sp.speaker: Lisa:
sp.p: And could you draw no blood of their wits:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Not a drop.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Nor demetrius neither, nor Manasses?

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p: Neither, to our own disgrace be it spoken, the carriage of their stratagem deserves applause, and I held it a credit to rest captive to such valiant conquerors?

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Why so be, I like a man that will confess his error.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: It merits commiseration madam and my liege, not to detract from our worth: your ear, we two are the parties you wot on.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Were you the men?

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: No he was the man, marry I was the woman in the moon, that made you walk all this last night like the man in the mist, I could say somewhat to you to Madam as for demetrius and his man let them stand like fools as they are.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Can it be possible.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: No, no, we are gulls, Innocent sots, but lante tanta, the girls are ours we have won them away to dargison.

sp.speaker: Lisa:
sp.p: Come we have won the conquest, and that is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: You are a manasses it is not sufficient: aha not Hercules for iole, Ioue, for Danue, Apollo for daphene, pan for Sirne, nay the whole pack of their piperly godheads could have discharged a stratagem with more spirit of all merit, an ambling nag and a-down a-down we have borne her away to dargison.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: It was the most rarest, divinest, Metaphisicalest, piece of invention, that, what say you my liege.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p: I give your deserts their full merit you have gotten equality

sp.speaker: Iulio:
sp.p: All the wenches gave you:

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Alas what spirits under the moon could have detained her but know that her cherry red lip, a-down, a-down.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: Trust me but you have deserved high commendation.

sp.speaker: Iulio:
sp.p: Your merit stood of the upper stair of admiration.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Why thou hast a pretty relish of wit, now that canst see the broad eye of my desert at a little hole of demonstration.

sp.speaker: iuli
sp.p:
your desert save me free, you have done a most (to use your own
phrase) Metaphysical piece of service, but you had some help in it questionless,

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: I do not think but the ladies had some hand in it:

sp.speaker: da,
sp.p: A finger, I confess a finger by the hope of perseverance, a very little finger.

sp.speaker: iuli,
sp.p: I thought as much by the making of the jest.

sp.speaker: Hip,
sp.p: I cannot detract from the ladies worth, for I know them for excellent work women,

sp.speaker: dam,
sp.p: work women fit to make tailors men.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Aye by my faith do I, nay your best tailors are arrant botchers to them, you shall have a lady make an end of a suit, a court suit, especially when all the tailors in a country know not how to set a stitch in it:

sp.speaker: dorus,
sp.p: Some ordinary suit perhaps.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: your best court suits that are, are finished by ladies, I have known a suit myself lien a making and marring three, four and five year together and then a lady hath dispatched it in a month with a wet finger, such a finger might the ladies have in your plot.

sp.speaker: de,
sp.p: never wet a finger by this sun.

sp.speaker: iuli
sp.p: Then she helped you with one dry jest or other, but if we may be so bold: faith where are the ladies?

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p: sure enough I warrant you, some fools now would have kept them here and have been gulled on them again, and laughed at again, but to prevent all danger, we have shipped them home for Lacedemon,

sp.speaker: Iulio:
sp.p: to Lacedemon, your sun of wit shines but dimly in that methinks, to whose charge have you trusted them?

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: to them we durst, nay you must think we are no fools,

sp.speaker: iu.
sp.p: Fools: nay deep wit, and policy forbid.

sp.speaker: Da,
sp.p: We had no sooner their surprisall, but we had disguise ready, a ship ready, a couple of lusty friends ready, the Lacedemons intelligencers:

sp.speaker: iuli
sp.p: durst you trust such precious jewels in such rusty caskets:

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: durst, our health, our lives: why they were my tenants, nay you must think we sifted them, we are no fools in that neither.

sp.speaker: hip:
sp.p: If in anything your wits deserve the babble it is in that,

sp.speaker: iuli:
sp.p: none but fools would have committed such inestimable peers to a couple of strangers:

sp.speaker: hip:
sp.p: And in a ship too,

sp.speaker: iu:
sp.p: And under sail too.

sp.speaker: dut:
sp.p: And unfurnished of friends too.

sp.speaker: du:
sp.p: And without shipping to follow them too.

sp.speaker: iu.
sp.p: you were no fools in anything but that, and in that not to flatter, you express the true shape of folly and merely merit the name of fools.

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p: What will you say now when these fellows surrender us our loves?

sp.speaker: Amt
sp.p: We will discharge you and see their names down for gulls in your stead.

sp.speaker: De:
sp.p: you know the proverb when the sky falls we shall have larks.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: And when you can bring proof that we are cozened of our Wenches we will be the woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Iulio:
sp.p: Why then we have once springed a couple of woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Amt:
sp.p: Do you know these? Who are the fools now?

sp.speaker: Deme:
sp.p: Violletta.

sp.speaker: Lisand:
sp.p: My Hippolita:

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: What a strange change is here:

sp.speaker: Hippo:
sp.p: yes faith gallants you have very strange carding if you knew all, but I hope you will offer up your cards and yield the set lost.

sp.speaker: dam,
sp.p: Gulls:

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: And abused I will lose my life before I lose my honour,

sp.speaker: dam.
sp.p: Honour, and life before I will lose my love:
Draw

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p: Nay gentlemen we bar all violence, the liberty of our challenge was to all alike equally free, and since these by fair play have won them, it stands with our honour to see them peaceably possessed of them, then surely take them, for though you wear the breeches give us leave to stand a little:

sp.speaker: Hippo:
sp.l: why father is it not time that we were sped
It is a great charge to keep a maidenhead,
Lose it we must and to prevent ill course,
Better to give it than have it stolen perforce,
If you be pleased let envy do her worst
Spit out her poison or contain it and burst?
Welcome to all, to all a kind god night,
They truly live, that live in scorn of spite.
